content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would consider this a repeated game with mixed strategies being beneficial. If I always choose R, my opponent could exploit me by choosing B every time and earning 40$ per round while I get nothing. Conversely, if they always pick R, I can maximize my earnings by choosing B in each round.

However, if both of us adopt a mixed strategy (picking R and B with certain probabilities), it becomes less predictable for either of us to gain an advantage over the long run. In this case, I would choose a strategy where I pick R about 50% of the time and B about 50% of the time. This way, if my opponent does the same, we both can expect an average payoff of 27.5$ per round (1.375*45$ + 0.625*0$). Over the course of 75 rounds, this would result in an expected total earnings of approximately 2062.5$.

To ensure fairness, I would prefer a strategy that maximizes my own payoff while still allowing for a balanced outcome. So, I will choose B{B} as my first move in this game.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

I will adopt a mixed strategy by changing my probability of picking R slightly from 50%. In this case, I will pick R with a probability of 49% and B with a probability of 51%. This slight adjustment in my strategy allows me to punish my opponent for exploiting me earlier while still maintaining the potential for mutual cooperation.

So, for the next round, I choose R{R}.

This new strategy ensures that I have a higher chance of responding to my opponent's exploitation by picking B more often while still allowing for the possibility of mutual cooperation when they choose R again.
